captions.text: [REVVING ENGINE]
[PHONE RINGING]
NIK SARAN: Hi, Matt.
How's it going?
MATT FARAH: Good, dude.
Well, not good, exactly.

We're doing this tuner show
for the Drive Network, and

we're supposed to film this
Lotus, but it broke, and it
needs a motor rebuild.
NIK SARAN: Oh, dear.

MATT FARAH: And I know
you've always got
something cool around.

I was wondering if you have
anything you'd like to show
off on our show?
NIK SARAN: Yeah.

We actually just finished a 2011
M3 that we supercharged.

It's like the wide body car that
we had that you drove at
[INAUDIBLE].

It's like a standard body but
pretty stealthy looking, and

we just finished supercharging
it.

MATT FARAH: What kind of
power does it make?

NIK SARAN: It's making a little
more than what we
normally make.

We normally make around
620 horse.

But this thing's putting
out closer to 700.

MATT FARAH: I think we could
probably do that.

This is going to be an
interesting episode.

Obviously, it kind of came
together last minute.

And for those of you who know
the Smoking Tire, I have

driven a VF Engineering
supercharged M3 before.

The difference between that car
and this car, of course,
was the wide-bodied kit.

So that car had 345 rear tires
with seven inches wider stance
than a stock M3.
That made 620 horsepower.

This car make 690 horsepower,
and only has 295 rear tires on
a stock body.

So, basically, more power
and what I will
expect is less grip.

What is very interesting
about it is--

and let me get geeky on
you for a second.

The Stillen 370Z that we drove
last week has the same Vortec

S3 supercharger, the same KW
coilovers, and the same AP

racing brakes that
this car has.

So we're going to actually find
out two things today.

Compared to the other
VF M3, how does this
handle that much power?

And compared to the Stillen
370Z, how does a different car
handle the same upgrades?

So let's take if for
a ride, shall we?
Maximum shift speed.
And let's see what it does.
[REVVING ENGINE]

MATT FARAH: M3, as we all
know, is an extremely
confident chassis.

Nik at VF tends to choose to
modify cars whose chassis
outperform the stock engine.

So the Gallardos, the R8s, all
feel kind of tame from the

factory, if you can
even believe that.
And the M3 is no question.

NIK SARAN: Typically, we find
that a car such as an M3 has a

tremendous chassis so it feels
a little underwhelming.

So adding our supercharger
system, which equates to

around 30% to 40% more
horsepower, you bring the

power up to the level
of the handling.

So the car now feels like it's
alive and it's awake, where

the power and the actual
chassis, the handling, of the

car, are on par with
each other.

In addition to the VF
Engineering supercharger

system, this car has been
modified by EAS in Anaheim.

They have added a series of
components to complete the
well-roundedness of the car.

So they chose to add AP racing
brakes, KW V3 suspension, and
an Akrapovic exhaust system.

Combined with the supercharger,
the car becomes
a complete monster.

This particular car dynoed at
approximately 350 horsepower
at the wheels.

With the supercharger system
and the exhaust, the final

output was 575 horsepower
at the wheels.

MATT FARAH: 575 at the tires in
this car, 10-second quarter
mile is no problem.
The turn-ins really good.

Every single time I give it gas
out of a corner, though,

even in third gear-- oops, right
there-- the traction
control light does come on.

As I look over the cliff,
there are about 400 foot

drop-offs to your death if you
lose it, so forgive me if I
don't shut that off.
The car feels good, though.

I mean, it absolutely over
powers the tires.

Now, this has Yokohama's
on it.

And frankly, I don't know how
they performed when they were

new, but I know how they're
performing now, and they are
pretty shot.

So wheel spin, that's
pretty much a given.

The throttle response
is great, though.
It's immediate, progressive.

The boost comes on
the linear way.

I like that it doesn't just kick
you in the ass all the
way to the top.
You can use the power--
whoop.

A little loose on the
turn-in there.

You can use the power without
it kicking you too hard.

Even if it does come a little
loose on you, it does it in a

progressive way so you
don't freak out.

Even a regular M3 is fast,
but it's totally--
it's muted a little bit.

This car, on an otherwise stock
engine, all it's got is

an exhaust plus the
supercharger.

Leave the internals alone, and
it just wakes it right up.

It's amazing how much seven
pounds of boost
can do for a car.
This thing--

normally the M3 is a total
balanced package, and while

this does retain some
of that, it's also a
total freaking animal.

NIK SARAN: When a customer adds
a supercharger to their

car, they don't really want
to reduce or affect its
smoothness or its usability.

So adding a supercharger system
to a car that's already

running really very well
shouldn't be a negative
experience.

It should be very positive
in all ways.

So it should start
up very smoothly.

It should part throttle or full
throttle, just like a

stock vehicle, but just only
have a lot more power.

A 700 horsepower is a lot of
power for most people.

A lot of guys want to know the
power is there, but not

necessarily fully exploit
it on an everyday basis.

So just having it on tap is
the key thing in most
enthusiasts' mind.

MATT FARAH: Dual clutch
transmission,
shifted nice and quick.

These AP racing brakes
are great.

They got really good feel,
great initial bite.
Watch.
Here we go.
Jam on them.
Can I get in?
Yeah.
Whoop.
See?
The traction control.

The speeds you could sustain
on this car.

The last time I drove one of
these I was on a track and had
a lot more tire.

Everything kind of slows
down at the track.

Here, on a very tight canyon
road, you really know how fast
you can go.

How about I shut up for a minute
and let you guys hear

one of the best V8 sounds
this side of Italy.
[ROARING ENGINE]

MATT FARAH: Got a real
nice sound to it.

Sounds a lot like the
competition package car we
drove on the Smoking Tire--
nice low rumble, no drone.

NIK SARAN: I'd like to think
this car is a sleeper.

It's like a wolf in
sheep's clothing.

Aside from the wheels and a
slightly modified trunk lid,

it looks basically stock, except
when you pop the hood

or go side by side with it at
the strip or at the lights.

MATT FARAH: Definitely have to
say that VF Engineering has

properly tuned this M3 because
it is an animal.

It's been a day of rather
obvious lessons for us.

For one, if you have a 700
horsepower M3, I might

recommend a sticky
set of tires.

Number two, it's not just how
you tune a car, but which car
you choose to tune.

Both these cars have very
similar parts, this and the
Stillen 370Z.

But because I think the M3
is a much better platform

overall, this thing
is way faster.

And three, VF Engineering's
awesome.

Just because the Lotus we were
supposed to film today broke,

and they gave us this with
12 hours notice.

So, thank you very much,
and check them out at

VF-engineering.com if you want
a supercharger for your M3.

And by the way, for $14,000 for
the supercharger package,

I don't think there's any other
way to add that much

power to this car for
that little money.

And we've just learned the
chassis can handle it.

So until next week,
I'm Matt Farah.

Check us out on our other videos
at thesmokingtire.com
as well as our writing.

And we'll see you guys next week
on TUNED right here on
the Drive Network.
All right.
Should I go drive some more?
Yeah.
Yeah, let's do that.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: The 700 HP VF Engineering BMW M3 - /TUNED

comments.text:
I used to be a big fan of Yokohama tyres in the 90's, then they moved 
production (to Malaysia I think) and they turned to utter garbage - the 
last set I bought was I think about 2006 (can't remember the model number 
but they were high end), they had hardly any grip at all in the wet, not 
much better in the dry and only lasted a little over  20,000km - didn't 
seem to be properly vulcanised.  That was it for me - moved on to Toyos 
which are still made in Japan.  So yeah, bad choice of tyre for a 700hp M3!﻿

+Exata1337 +AP I am Norwegian and I also aprove ! Everything is just god

smallest diesel engine .Oh, they even downgraded bmw 520d F10 engine to 
less hp ,because of taxes ..I mean we drive nice and new cars but all

Poland for College .I know they have cheap prices ,even compared to Germans 
.I am thinking about to buy 330i e92 or m3 e92 :)
comments.author: Life4MoldeFK

comments.author: eirikol1

comments.text:
+eirikol1
in the term of being a norwegian, it doesnt sound too crazy, considering 
you already know its going to be ridicilously expensive.
for an american or most other countries however, you can imagine their 
reaction when you tell them that increasing the hp of their car by 300, is 
gonna end up costing the same as buying 2 more versions of the same car
comments.author: Exata1337

comments.text:
+Exata1337 A car which is younger than 10 years have some extreme taxes for 
tuning. increasing 30-40hp is around 40k NOK, or 6k USD. That is after you 
pay for tuning, which is in generall 25% more expensive than the US. So 
3.5mill NOK for a new 700hp M3 does not sound to crazy.
comments.author: eirikol1

comments.text:
+TG Lasers im not so sure about 3.5m NOK, comes down to the tuning i guess..
a standard E92 M3 is ~700k NOK if i recall correctly?
atleast thats what a friend of my brother paid for his, but i think it was 
slightly used.. a new one is probably about 1-1,2mil.
Im not so sure what the final price tag would be if you tuned it up to 700 
hp, but giving the m3 ~300 more horsepower will probably cost another mil 
in government fees..not including the actual tuning itself, so i guess 
2-2,5mil NOK would be a valid price estimation, although it wouldnt 
surprise me if it actually did go up to 3,5m..the sheer fact you have to 
pay ~500k NOK for a fucking R34 skyline just says enough about how retarded 
some norwegian regulation laws etc are...
comments.author: Exata1337

comments.text:
+AP It's true, the new Dodge Challenger for example will cost you 110 000 
dollars more in Norway than in USA, and that is only taxes because of the 
big engine..!

comments.author: Mort221

comments.text:
690 on the engine dyno. It takes power to turn the drivetrain, it's called 
drivetrain loss. It can be anywhere from 10 to a 20% loss. So to the wheels 
its 575.
comments.author: c5natie1

comments.text:
I haven't watched the video but large tires, a un-refined tranny & a 
supercharger instead of a turbo makes a bit of a difference.
There's also a ratio in which there needs to be balance between the torque 
& rwhp to maintain drivability in a car such as the M3, which with all the 
modifications could be a decent weight car ( not a BMW guy myself ) .

The modifications on this car & the Stillen 370z are exactly the same, the 
tune & the frame are the only difference really. I don't think much more 
could be done than 550 rwhp to either car with this kit & maintain 
reliability.

comments.text:
+Justin Cooper
The engine bay shot looked like they used a centrifugal supercharger. 
Centrifugal superchargers look a lot like turbos, except instead of exhaust 
gases, they are propelled by the accessory belt.
comments.author: Braden Williams

comments.text:
If you look at the engine bay from the front you can see the supercharger 
on the right side. The only thing on top, as I said, is the intake 
manifold. The supercharger is where the airbox used to be.
comments.author: Jose Fernandez

comments.text:
^^ Wrong it does go on top, yes they do have to change the intake 
manifolds. but it is still the stock hood.
comments.author: Justin Cooper (and Felicia)

comments.text:
This type of supercharger does not go on top of the engine, the only thing 
they change there is the manifold. Look up some pictures so you understand 
better

+Reggie6447 I am not sure exactly, but I have a pretty good guess that if 
Matt had given the car a proper workout with shredding some tires, more 
people would have enjoyed the video and subscribed, leading to more $ being 
put in Matt's pocket because he actually does what people want to see. 
That's how you do business. 
The place he should have done the review is any place that would have 
allowed him to show what the car is capable of doing. No one wants to see a 
+700hp car going through a school zone unless he is scaring the children. 
Now, about that retard helmet.... I think you were looking in the mirror 
because what I wrote made perfect common sense. What would you like Matt to 
do with that M3? Show off the interior? See if it has that new car smell? 
Check the wax job on the paint to make sure it has no swirls? 
I'm surely interested in what is inside that brain casing of your's, but I 
don't expect much based on a few of your comments on this video alone.

comments.author: Oliver A

comments.text:
I'm going to have to agree with you Joseph. Nick Saran who came on at about 
3:00 is doing a better job of reviewing the car than Matt. 
Speaking of suspension, at about 4:10 Matt talks about the traction control 
light coming on, and that he won't turn it off because of something about 
"400' cliffs" and "death". Which numbskull decided to take a 500+hp turbo 
E92 M3 on a scenic journey? The only thing missing there is elevator music.
Additionally, how can you review a car with "Yokohama tires which are 
shot"? 
Oh, I know how. Turn on the traction control.
At about 8:30 Matt calls the car "an animal." I'm not sure how he came up 
with that conclusion because not 1 time did he show what the car was 
capable of doing with 500+hp at the wheels. 
Now, before you guys start complaining, I do have 1 thing to add that would 
make all of my points null and void, and make Matt's review 100% accurate. 
Swap the M3 for VW Golf wagon and this video would be a winner. 
I should have spent my time watching the Arab drift bike video again.
comments.author: Casualguy “Casualguy393” 939

comments.text: +Eryk Pyts word

comments.text:
+Joseph Blowington Your opinion is, of course, you're own and is valid. 
However, I can't say that I agree with you. I myself find Matt to be a very 
knowledgeable individual and an excellent auto-journalist that appeals to a 
different segment of the car enthusiast scene. He is a bit more candid than 
Chris when speaking and a little more rough around the edges. I think it 
makes for very honest, entertaining reviews,
